p: It is now clear that the canine host range of CPV was primarily associated with changes in the capsid protein gene, with only a few key residues on the capsid surface allowing the virus to infect dog cells [ 57, 58]. The main host range variation and emergence events are outlined in figureÂ 3. CPV uses the cellular transferrin receptor type-1 (TfR) as the receptor for entry [ 59]. Comparing the sequences of the TfRs from different hosts identified a key change in the canine TfR as an additional glycosylation site in a position where it blocks the binding of FPV-like viruses [ 57]. That additional glycosylation site is found in a few animal hosts closely related to dogs (wolves, coyotes, possibly golden jackals) [ 60, 61].
